metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Git Branch
Change Platform:
What is a Git Branch?
In Git, a branch is like a separate workspace where you can make changes and try new ideas without affecting the main project. Think of it as a "parallel universe" for your code.
content.html: In Git, a branch is like a separate workspace where you can make changes and try new ideas without affecting the main project. Think of it as a "parallel universe" for your code.

content.text: Why Use Branches?
Branches let you work on different parts of a project, like new features or bug fixes, without interfering with the main branch.
content.html: Branches let you work on different parts of a project, like new features or bug fixes, without interfering with the main branch.

content.text: Common Reasons to Create a Branch
Example: With and Without Git
Let's say you have a large project, and you need to update the design on it.
content.html: Let's say you have a large project, and you need to update the design on it.

content.text: How would that work without and with Git:
content.html: How would that work without and with Git:

content.text: Without Git:
With Git:
Branches allow you to work on different parts of a project without impacting the main branch.
content.html: Branches allow you to work on different parts of a project without impacting the main branch.

content.text: When the work is complete, a branch can be merged with the main project.
content.html: When the work is complete, a branch can be merged with the main project.

content.text: You can even switch between branches and work on different projects without them interfering with each other.
content.html: You can even switch between branches and work on different projects without them interfering with each other.

content.text: Branching in Git is very lightweight and fast!
content.html: Branching in Git is very lightweight and fast!

content.text: Creating a New Branch
Let's say you want to add a new feature. You can create a new branch for it.
content.html: Let's say you want to add a new feature. You can create a new branch for it.

content.text: Let add some new features to our index.html page.
content.html: Let add some new features to our index.html page.

content.text: We are working in our local repository, and we do not want to disturb or possibly wreck the main project.
content.html: We are working in our local repository, and we do not want to disturb or possibly wreck the main project.

content.text: So we create a new branch :
content.html: So we create a new branch:

content.code_html: git branch hello-world-images

content.text: Now we created a new branch called " hello-world-images "
content.html: Now we created a new branch called "hello-world-images"

content.text: Listing All Branches
Let's confirm that we have created a new branch .
content.html: Let's confirm that we have created a new branch.

content.text: To see all branches in your repository, use:
content.html: To see all branches in your repository, use:

content.code_html:
git branch
  hello-world-images
* master

content.text: We can see the new branch with the name "hello-world-images", but the * beside master specifies that we are currently on that branch .
content.html: We can see the new branch with the name "hello-world-images", but the * beside master specifies that we are currently on that branch.

content.text: Switching Between Branches
checkout is the command used to check out a branch .
content.html: checkout is the command used to check out a branch.

content.text: Moving us from the current branch , to the one specified at the end of the command:
content.html: Moving us from the current branch, to the one specified at the end of the command:

content.code:
git
checkout hello-world-images
Switched to branch 'hello-world-images'
content.code_html:
git checkout hello-world-images
Switched to branch 'hello-world-images'

content.text: Now you can work in your new branch without affecting the main branch.
content.html: Now you can work in your new branch without affecting the main branch.

content.text: Working in a Branch
Now we have moved our current workspace from the master branch, to the new branch
content.html: Now we have moved our current workspace from the master branch, to the new branch

content.text: Open your favourite editor and make some changes.
content.html: Open your favourite editor and make some changes.

content.text: For this example, we added an image (img_hello_world.jpg) to the working folder and a line of code in the index.html file:
content.html: For this example, we added an image (img_hello_world.jpg) to the working folder and a line of code in the index.html file:

content.code:
Hello world!

This is the first file in my new Git Repo.

A new line in our file!
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Hello World!</title>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="bluestyle.css">
</head>
<body>

<h1>Hello world!</h1>
<div><img src="img_hello_world.jpg" alt="Hello World from Space"
style="width:100%;max-width:960px"></div>
<p>This is the first file in my new Git Repo.</p>
<p>A new line in our file!</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: We have made changes to a file and added a new file in the working directory (same directory as the main branch ).
content.html: We have made changes to a file and added a new file in the working directory (same directory as the main branch).

content.text: Now check the status of the current branch :
content.html: Now check the status of the current branch:

content.code:
git
status
On branch hello-world-images
Changes not staged for commit:
(use "git add
..." to update what will be committed)
(use "git restore
..." to discard changes in working directory)
modified:   index.html

Untracked files:
(use "git add
..." to include in what will be committed)
img_hello_world.jpg

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
content.code_html:
git status
On branch hello-world-images
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add ..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore ..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   index.html

Untracked files:
  (use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed)
        img_hello_world.jpg

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

content.text: So let's go through what happens here:
content.html: So let's go through what happens here:

content.text: So we need to add both files to the Staging Environment for this branch :
content.html: So we need to add both files to the Staging Environment for this branch:

content.code_html: git add --all

content.text: Using --all instead of individual filenames will Stage all changed (new, modified, and deleted) files.
content.html: Using --all instead of individual filenames will Stage all changed (new, modified, and deleted) files.

content.text: Check the status of the branch :
content.html: Check the status of the branch:

content.code:
git
status
On branch hello-world-images
Changes to be committed:
(use "git restore --staged
..." to unstage)
new file: img_hello_world.jpg
modified: index.html
content.code_html:
git status
On branch hello-world-images
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged ..." to unstage)
    new file: img_hello_world.jpg
    modified: index.html

content.text: We are happy with our changes. So we will commit them to the branch :
content.html: We are happy with our changes. So we will commit them to the branch:

content.code:
git
commit -m
"Added image to Hello World"

[hello-world-images 0312c55] Added image to Hello World
2 files changed, 1 insertion(+)
create mode 100644 img_hello_world.jpg
content.code_html:
git commit -m "Added image to Hello World"
[hello-world-images 0312c55] Added image to Hello World
2 files changed, 1 insertion(+)
create mode 100644 img_hello_world.jpg

content.text: Now we have a new branch , that is different from the master branch .
content.html: Now we have a new branch, that is different from the master branch.

content.text: Note: Using the -b option on checkout will create a new branch, and move to it, if it does not exist
content.html: Note: Using the -b option on checkout will create a new branch, and move to it, if it does not exist

content.text: Switching Between Branches
Now let's see just how quick and easy it is to work with different branches, and how well it works.
content.html: Now let's see just how quick and easy it is to work with different branches, and how well it works.

content.text: We are currently on the branch hello-world-images . We added an image to this branch, so let's list the files in the current directory:
content.html: We are currently on the branch hello-world-images. We added an image to this branch, so let's list the files in the current directory:

content.code_html:
ls
README.md  bluestyle.css  img_hello_world.jpg  index.html

content.text: We can see the new file img_hello_world.jpg , and if we open the html file, we can see the code has been altered. All is as it should be.
content.html: We can see the new file img_hello_world.jpg, and if we open the html file, we can see the code has been altered. All is as it should be.

content.text: Now, let's see what happens when we change branch to master
content.html: Now, let's see what happens when we change branch to master

content.code:
git
checkout master
Switched to branch 'master'
content.code_html:
git checkout master
Switched to branch 'master'

content.text: The new image is not a part of this branch. List the files in the current directory again:
content.html: The new image is not a part of this branch. List the files in the current directory again:

content.code_html:
ls
README.md  bluestyle.css  index.html

content.text: img_hello_world.jpg is no longer there! And if we open the html file, we can see the code reverted to what it was before the alteration.
content.html: img_hello_world.jpg is no longer there! And if we open the html file, we can see the code reverted to what it was before the alteration.

content.text: See how easy it is to work with branches? And how this allows you to work on different things?
content.html: See how easy it is to work with branches? And how this allows you to work on different things?

content.text: Emergency Branch
Now imagine that we are not yet done with hello-world-images, but we need to fix an error on master.
content.html: Now imagine that we are not yet done with hello-world-images, but we need to fix an error on master.

content.text: I don't want to mess with master directly, and I do not want to mess with hello-world-images, since it is not done yet.
content.html: I don't want to mess with master directly, and I do not want to mess with hello-world-images, since it is not done yet.

content.text: So we create a new branch to deal with the emergency:
content.html: So we create a new branch to deal with the emergency:

content.code:
git
checkout -b emergency-fix
Switched to a new branch 'emergency-fix'
content.code_html:
git checkout -b emergency-fix
Switched to a new branch 'emergency-fix'

content.text: Now we have created a new branch from master, and changed to it. We can safely fix the error without disturbing the other branches.
content.html: Now we have created a new branch from master, and changed to it. We can safely fix the error without disturbing the other branches.

content.text: Let's fix our imaginary error:
content.html: Let's fix our imaginary error:

content.code:
Hello world!

This is the first file in my new Git Repo.

This line is here to show how merging works.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Hello World!</title>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="bluestyle.css">
</head>
<body>

<h1>Hello world!</h1>
<p>This is the first file in my new Git Repo.</p>
<p>This line is here to show how merging works.</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: We have made changes in this file, and we need to get those changes to the master branch.
content.html: We have made changes in this file, and we need to get those changes to the master branch.

content.text: Check the status:
content.html: Check the status:

content.code:
git
status
On branch emergency-fix
Changes not staged for commit:
(use "git add
..." to update what will be committed)
(use "git restore
..." to discard changes in working directory)
modified:   index.html

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
content.code_html:
git status
On branch emergency-fix
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add ..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore ..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   index.html

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

content.text: stage the file, and commit:
content.html: stage the file, and commit:

content.code:
git

add
index.html

git
commit -m
"updated index.html with emergency fix"

[emergency-fix dfa79db] updated index.html with emergency fix
1 file changed, 1 insertion(+), 1 deletion(-)
content.code_html:
git add index.html
git commit -m "updated index.html with emergency fix"
[emergency-fix dfa79db] updated index.html with emergency fix
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+), 1 deletion(-)

content.text: Now we have a fix ready for master, and we need to merge the two branches.
content.html: Now we have a fix ready for master, and we need to merge the two branches.

content.text: Deleting a Branch
When you're done with a branch, you can delete it:
content.html: When you're done with a branch, you can delete it:

content.code_html: git branch -d hello-world-images

content.text: This deletes the branch named hello-world-images (if it's already merged).
content.html: This deletes the branch named hello-world-images (if it's already merged).

content.text: Best Practices for Working with Branches
Practical Examples
Troubleshooting
If you don't see your changes on the main branch, remember: changes in one branch stay there until you merge them.
content.html: If you don't see your changes on the main branch, remember: changes in one branch stay there until you merge them.

content.text: When deleting a branch, make sure it's merged first. If you try to delete an unmerged branch, Git will prevent you from doing so.
content.html: When deleting a branch, make sure it's merged first. If you try to delete an unmerged branch, Git will prevent you from doing so.

content.text: To force delete an unmerged branch, use git branch -D branch-name .
content.html: To force delete an unmerged branch, use git branch -D branch-name.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which command switches to an existing branch?
content.html: Which command switches to an existing branch?
